stream_context.summary: Kaze wraps up Course 14 “Handmade Heights” (star names, Peach NPC, Yoshi-coin reward) and begins blue-sky planning for Course 15 “Astral Arcade,” an outer-space arcade/casino level that will sit atop a Rainbow Road-style setting. Technical tasks include importing Badub’s “Funky Space Casino” track, trimming unused music to keep the ROM at 58 MB, and debugging a looping-star bug. The stream also shows Kaze’s philosophy on memory limits, Expansion Pak use, and avoidance of real-gambling mechanics.

development_findings.summary: Course 14 is functionally complete; only a Peach cut-out animation from Yuki/Zeina is still missing.
development_findings.quote: Honestly kind of done … All that's missing is one asset, which I'm still waiting for from Yuki.

development_findings.summary: Peach NPC now grants a Yoshi coin after the player defeats three ‘thimble guys’ and talks to her; she will need separate sad and happy animations.
Kaze uses the 8 MB Expansion Pak during development to load all code and level data at once, but intends to ship the hack within a self-imposed 64 MB ROM limit to stay authentic.
development_findings.quote: I want to stick to the 64 megabyte limit because that's what they worked with back in the day. Going over that would feel like cheating.

development_findings.summary: Imported Badub’s pre-rendered ‘Funky Space Casino’ track for Course 15; after removing four unused songs, total ROM size is down to 58 MB.

Initial design pillars for Course 15: a giant rocket/arcade in space, low-gravity zones marked by scrolling green lines, black-hole portals to distant sub-areas, and mini-games accessed via arcade cabinets (e.g., whack-a-mole, rhythm platforming, moon-destroying asteroid game). Gambling mechanics are explicitly avoided.
Black-hole teleport system is already coded and will be reused to make the level feel larger.
Entire project now compiles from C source rather than assembly inserts, improving readability and maintainability.
A playable demo is planned once two pending videos are edited; Kaze hopes to release it by year’s end.

context_findings.summary: Kaze will sacrifice optimization time by relying on the Expansion Pak because it ‘reduces the development time a lot.’
He would only consider working for Nintendo if offered roughly $110–120 k and the freedom to keep making his own games; otherwise, it would ‘curb a lot of my ambition.’
Rants against ARG clichés and praises Majora’s Mask, revealing design taste for meaningful puzzles over contrived ones.
He is scripting a video about the N64’s hidden half-megabyte of RAM and expects it to ‘do really well.’
Expresses mild frustration with a star-granting infinite loop bug but shows excitement when Course 14 compiles cleanly.
Mentions easy success getting monetized on Twitter, pointing to diversified income streams.

biobak.summary: Provided real-time feedback on Course 15 concepts and asset reuse possibilities.

badub.summary: Composed ‘Funky Space Casino’ (Course 15 BGM) and shared it on SoundCloud; usually supplies exact loop points for tracks.

zeina.summary: Tasked with animating the Peach cut-out (sad/happy states) needed to fully close Course 14.

key_stories.title: Bringing Course 14 Across the Finish Line
key_stories.summary: Course 14 needed star names, a working Peach NPC, and one last animation. Kaze brainstormed names live, coded Peach’s Yoshi-coin reward, and hunted a bug that caused the star to loop indefinitely.
key_stories.challenge: Finalize assets and eliminate a game-breaking loop.
key_stories.process: Live star-name brainstorming; coding of NPC logic; debugging list-head oversight; awaiting Zeina’s animation.
key_stories.outcome: Level declared complete except for Peach animation.
key_stories.key_quote: Honestly kind of done … All that's missing is one asset.

key_stories.title: The Self-Imposed 64 MB Ceiling
key_stories.summary: Although the Expansion Pak lets him ignore RAM constraints during development, Kaze insists the final ROM not exceed 64 MB to honor the N64’s historical limits.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing modern conveniences with retro authenticity.
key_stories.process: Used pre-rendered music, then cut four unused tracks; monitored ROM size after each build.
key_stories.outcome: ROM presently at 58 MB, giving headroom for new courses.
key_stories.key_quote: Going over that would feel like cheating.

key_stories.title: Inventing ‘Astral Arcade’
key_stories.summary: Kaze starts with a vague ‘space casino’ idea and, with chat and Biobak, iterates toward a rocket-shaped arcade sitting on Rainbow Road, featuring low-gravity zones, black-hole portals, and mini-game cabinets that alter the overworld.
key_stories.challenge: Design a final course that feels expansive, coherent, and non-gambling.
key_stories.process: Live white-board of mechanics (whack-a-mole, moon explosion, pinball platforms), aesthetic choices (pixel art, moon rocks), and technical hooks (cloud cap, black holes).
key_stories.outcome: A rough design doc with multiple sub-areas and stars but open implementation details.
key_stories.key_quote: What if someone built an arcade on top of the Rainbow Road?

open_questions.context: Course 14 can’t fully close until Zeina (referred to as Yuki) delivers the sad and happy Peach animations.
questions: What is the scope and progress of the Peach cut-out animations?
How does Zeina integrate her art pipeline with Kaze’s code?
Will similar NPC animations be needed in later levels?

open_questions.context: Kaze envisions low-gravity zones marked by scrolling lines and black-hole portals to enlarge Course 15.
questions: How will low-gravity physics be tuned to stay fun but controllable?
What technical hurdles exist in placing multiple black holes in one level?
Could these mechanics be reused in earlier courses to create cohesion?

open_questions.context: Idea to destroy a 2D moon in an arcade game and have the 3D moon outside explode.
questions: What other environmental changes can arcade games trigger?
How will the team prevent mini-games from feeling tacked on or gimmicky?
Who will handle the additional art and code load for these sequences?

open_questions.context: Pre-rendered tracks eat ROM but render quickly; sequenced music saves space.
questions: What criteria decide whether a track is pre-rendered or sequenced?
Could dynamic music layering reduce space without losing quality?
How will the 64 MB ceiling influence future musical choices?

open_questions.context: Kaze says the public demo will drop after two videos are edited.
questions: Which videos are gating the demo release?
What content will the demo include?
Is there a promotional plan once the demo is out?

open_questions.context: Contributors (Biobak, Badub, Zeina) appear in chat but their formal workflow is unclear.
questions: What collaboration tools and version control does the team use?
How are tasks assigned and tracked?
How has remote collaboration shaped the project’s schedule?
